user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskFindIdBySystemData:
```c
int32 OS_TaskFindIdBySystemData(osal_id_t *task_id, const void *sysdata, size_t sysdata_size)
{
    int32             return_code;
    OS_object_token_t token;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(task_id);

    /* The "sysdata" and "sysdata_size" must be passed to the underlying impl for validation */
    return_code = OS_TaskValidateSystemData_Impl(sysdata, sysdata_size);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, OS_TaskIdMatchSystemData_Impl,
                                         (void *)sysdata, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        *task_id = OS_ObjectIdFromToken(&token);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TaskFindIdBySystemData:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
int32 OS_TaskValidateSystemData_Impl(const void *sysdata, size_t sysdata_size)
{
    if (sysdata == NULL || sysdata_size != sizeof(pthread_t))
    {
        return OS_INVALID_POINTER;
    }
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t MatchFunc, void *arg,
                             OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdFindNextMatch(MatchFunc, arg, token);

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "lock_mode" parameter.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }
    else
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
bool OS_TaskIdMatchSystemData_Impl(void *ref, const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_common_record_t *obj)
{
    const pthread_t *               target = (const pthread_t *)ref;
    OS_impl_task_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_task_table, *token);

    return (pthread_equal(*target, impl->id) != 0);
}
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
static inline osal_id_t OS_ObjectIdFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_id;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The fragments above are places where control flow can cause other code to be bypassed (early returns, conditional branches, token conversion/cancellation, and dereferences dependent on prior validation). They should be investigated to ensure no code becomes permanently unreachable under realistic inputs and to verify the macros/functions (e.g. OS_CHECK_POINTER / BUGCHECK, OS_ObjectIdConvertToken, OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel, OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET) do not hide unconditional exits or leave states that make subsequent code unreachable. Other lines in the provided snippets are simple declarations, assignments, or straightforward returns and do not by themselves create unreachable code paths, so they do not need investigation for Rule 2.1 based on the supplied context.
